text:
See R code







Highest-grossing tours of all time visualization



Let‚Äôs get started by loading the necessary R packages to clean, scrape, and visualize the data. These packages are the building blocks of our data scraping journey.

# To clean data
library(tidyverse)
library(janitor)

# To scrape data
library(rvest)
library(httr)
library(polite)

# To visualize data
library(ggplot2)
library(showtext)
library(viridis)

font_add_google("Playfair Display", "playfair-display")
font_add_google("Lato", "lato")

showtext::showtext_auto()

Now that we have the necessary libraries loaded, it‚Äôs time to politely scrape data from Wikipedia and bring it into R. We‚Äôll start by specifying the URL of the Wikipedia page we want to extract data from:

url <-
  "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_highest-grossing_concert_tours"

Next, we‚Äôll use the polite package to create a ‚Äòbag of words‚Äô (bow) representation of the URL. This step helps us make a polite request to the web server for the page‚Äôs content:

url_bow <- polite::bow(url)
url_bow

<polite session> https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_highest-grossing_concert_tours
    User-agent: polite R package
    robots.txt: 456 rules are defined for 33 bots
   Crawl delay: 5 sec
  The path is scrapable for this user-agent


Once we have our ‚Äòbow,‚Äô we can use it to scrape the web page. We‚Äôll specifically target the tables with the class ‚Äòwikitable‚Äô on the page:

ind_html <-
  polite::scrape(url_bow) |>  # scrape web page
  rvest::html_nodes("table.wikitable") |> # pull out specific table
  rvest::html_table(fill = TRUE) 

Finally, we‚Äôll clean up the extracted table (the second table on the page, Top 20 highest-grossing tours of all time) by storing it in the ind_tab variable and ensuring that column names are in a consistent format:

ind_tab <- 
  ind_html[[2]] |> 
  clean_names()

This code segment efficiently fetches and prepares the data we need from the Wikipedia page. Our next step is to clean it for analysis. In this code snippet, we‚Äôll perform some essential data cleaning tasks to make our dataset ready for exploration: transforming the Adjusted Gross in 2022 Dollars, Actual Gross, and Average Gross columns into numeric variables.

ind_tab_clean <-
  ind_tab |>
  dplyr::mutate(across(
    c(adjusted_gross_in_2022_dollars,
      actual_gross,
      averagegross),
    ~ as.numeric(str_replace_all(.x, "[$,]", ""))
  ))

We want to add Taylor‚Äôs data:

ind_tab_tay <-
  ind_tab_clean |> 
  add_row(artist = "Taylor Swift",
          tour_title = "The Eras Tour (Expected)",
          year_s = "2023-2024",
          shows = 146,
          adjusted_gross_in_2022_dollars = 1400000000,
          .before = 1)

Now that our data is clean and ready, let‚Äôs visualize the highest-grossing concert tours of all time (as of 2023) using a bar chart. We‚Äôll use the ggplot2 package.

ind_tab_tay |>
  slice(1:10) |> 
  mutate(color = case_when(artist == "Taylor Swift" ~ "#D3ABD0",
                           .default = "#903345")) |>
  ggplot(aes(
    x = forcats::fct_reorder(tour_title,
                             adjusted_gross_in_2022_dollars),
    y = adjusted_gross_in_2022_dollars
  )) +
  geom_col(aes(fill = color),
           color = "black",
           width = .9) +
  scale_fill_identity() +
  labs(title = "Highest-grossing tours of all time",
       subtitle = "(as of 2023)") +
  theme(
    text = element_text(size = 9,
                        family = "lato"),
    title = element_text(
      size = 16,
      family = "playfair-display"
    ),
    subtitle = element_text(size = 12,
                            family = "lato")
  ) +
  geom_text(
    aes(y = 12000000, label = tour_title),
    family = "lato",
    hjust = 0,
    vjust = 0.5,
    size = 3,
    color = "white",
    fontface = "bold"
  ) +
  geom_text(
    aes(
      y = 12000000,
      label = ifelse(artist == "Taylor Swift", tour_title, "")
    ),
    family = "lato",
    hjust = 0,
    vjust = 0.5,
    size = 3,
    color = "black",
    fontface = "bold"
  ) +
  geom_text(
    aes(
      label = scales::dollar(
        adjusted_gross_in_2022_dollars,
        accuracy = 1,
        scale = 1e-6,
        suffix = "M"
      )
    ),
    family = "lato",
    hjust = -0.1,
    vjust = 0.5,
    size = 3
  ) +
  coord_flip() +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 1500000000)) +
  theme_void()

See R code







Tip




combine_data <- function(ind_html_list) {
  # Initialize an empty tibble
  combined_data <- tibble()
  
  # Loop through the ind_html_list and append each element to the combined_data
  for (i in 4:8) {
    extracted_data <- ind_html_list[[i]] |> clean_names()
    combined_data <- bind_rows(combined_data, extracted_data)
  }
  
  return(combined_data)
}

annual_hi_gross_tours <- combine_data(ind_html)


tours_by_decade <-
  annual_hi_gross_tours |>
  dplyr::mutate(across(
    c(adjusted_gross_in_2022_dollar,
      averagegross,
      actual_gross),
    ~ as.numeric(str_replace_all(.x, "[$,]", ""))
  )) |>
     add_row(artist = "Taylor Swift",
          tour_title = "The Eras Tour (Expected)",
          year_s = "2023-2024",
          shows = 146,
          adjusted_gross_in_2022_dollar = 1400000000) |> 
  mutate(
    start_year = str_sub(year_s, start = 1, end = 4),
    year = lubridate::ymd(start_year, truncated = 2L)) |> 
  mutate(decade = as.factor(floor_date(year, years(10))))


g1 <- subset(tours_by_decade, tour_title == "The Eras Tour (Expected)")

tours_by_decade |>
  ggplot(aes(
    x = year,
    y = adjusted_gross_in_2022_dollar,
    size =  shows,
    fill = decade
  )) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5,
             shape = 21,
             color = "black") +
  scale_size(range = c(.1, 8)) +
  scale_fill_viridis(discrete = TRUE,
                     guide = FALSE,
                     option = "G") +
  theme_minimal() +
  geom_point(data = g1, colour = "#122B2B") +
  geom_text(
    data = g1,
    label = "Taylor Swift",
    vjust = 2.4,
    size = 3
  ) +
  theme(legend.position = "none") +
  labs(title = "Highest-grossing tours by decade") +
  scale_x_date(limits = c(ymd("1980-01-01"), ymd("2028-01-01")))





tours_by_decade |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = shows, y = adjusted_gross_in_2022_dollar)) +
  geom_point()





tours_by_decade |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = shows, y = adjusted_gross_in_2022_dollar)) +
  geom_point()

See R code







Tip




library(httr)
library(jsonlite)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)
library(purrr)
library(readr)
library(glue)

get_artist_data <- function(artist_name, songstats_artist_id) {
  url <-
    "https://api.songstats.com/enterprise/v1/artists/historic_stats"
  
  queryString <- list(
    source = "all",
    songstats_artist_id = songstats_artist_id,
    start_date = "2020-01-01"
  )
  
  response <- httr::VERB(
    "GET",
    url,
    query = queryString,
    add_headers(
      "Accept-Encoding" = "",
      "apikey" = Sys.getenv("SONGSTATS_TOKEN")
    ),
    content_type("application/octet-stream"),
    accept("application/json")
  )
  
  artist_data <- httr::content(response, "text")
  
  artist_tibble <- artist_data |>
    jsonlite::fromJSON() |>
    purrr::map_if(is.data.frame, list) |>
    as.data.frame() |>
    tidyr::unnest_wider(stats.data) |>
    tidyr::unnest(history) |>
    dplyr::mutate(
      time_frame = dplyr::case_when(date < "2022-11-01" ~ "before announcement",
                                    .default = "after announcement"),
      artist = artist_name
    )
  
  file_name <- glue::glue("{artist_name}_tibble.Rds")
  readr::write_rds(artist_tibble, "data/file_name")
  
  return(artist_tibble)
}

# Create a list of artists and their IDs
artists <- list(
  c("Paramore", "p5xm8h7b"),
  c("Beabadoobee", "n3k29evr"),
  c("Phoebe Bridgers", "9yhbd1el"),
  c("Girl In Red", "p71m4gr8"),
  c("MUNA", "fyxmowt5"),
  c("HAIM", "apuz50ix"),
  c("GAYLE", "q16uf7gk"),
  c("OWENN", "cztp0nug"),
  c("Gracie Abrams", "so4cd0bt"),
  c("Taylor Swift", "i5muw4xf")
)

artist_data_list <-
  map(artists, ~ get_artist_data(.x[1], .x[2]))

combined_artist_data <-
  bind_rows(artist_data_list)

write_rds(combined_artist_data, "data/combined_artist_data.rds")

See R code







The Eras Tour Dates and Venues




# To clean data
library(tidyverse)
library(janitor)

# To scrape data
library(rvest)
library(httr)
library(polite)

# To geocode data
library(tidygeocoder)

# To visualize data
library(leaflet)


url_map <-
  "https://www.sportskeeda.com/pop-culture/taylor-swift-2023-the-eras-tour-ticket-cities-and-dates"

url_map_bow <- polite::bow(url_map)
url_map_bow

<polite session> https://www.sportskeeda.com/pop-culture/taylor-swift-2023-the-eras-tour-ticket-cities-and-dates
    User-agent: polite R package
    robots.txt: 41 rules are defined for 4 bots
   Crawl delay: 5 sec
  The path is scrapable for this user-agent



map_html <-
  polite::scrape(url_map_bow) |>  # scrape web page
  rvest::html_nodes("tbody") |> # pull out specific table
  rvest::html_table(fill = TRUE) |>
  bind_rows() |>
  row_to_names(row_number = 1) |>
  clean_names()


map_html_geocode <-
  map_html |>
  geocode(venue,
          method = "osm",
          lat = latitude ,
          long = longitude)

map_html_geo <-
  map_html_geocode |>
  mutate(
    latitude = case_when(
      venue == "Empower Field at Mile Hi" ~ 39.74359,
      venue == "Johan Cruyff Arena" ~ 52.3143,
      .default = latitude
    ),
    longitude = case_when(
      venue == "Empower Field at Mile Hi" ~ -105.01968,
      venue == "Johan Cruyff Arena" ~ 4.94187,
      .default = longitude
    )
  ) |>
  mutate(number_shows = n(),
         .by = c(venue, city)) |>
  mutate(occurred = case_when(lubridate::mdy(paste0(date, year)) < today() ~ "Occurred",
                              .default = "Not Occurred"))

Warning: There was 1 warning in `mutate()`.
‚Ñπ In argument: `occurred = case_when(...)`.
Caused by warning:
!  24 failed to parse.



pal <- colorFactor(
  palette = c("#823549", "#1D1F38"),
  domain = map_html_geo$occurred
)

leaflet(options = leafletOptions(minZoom = 10, maxZoom = 10)) |>
  addProviderTiles("Esri.WorldGrayCanvas",
                   options = (noWrap = TRUE)) |>
  setMaxBounds(
    lng1 = 180,
    lat1 = 90,
    lng2 = -180,
    lat2 = -90
  ) |> 
  addCircleMarkers(
    data = map_html_geo,
    color = ~pal(occurred),
    label = paste(
      "Venue: ",
      map_html_geo$venue,
      "<br>",
      "City: ",
      map_html_geo$city,
      "<br>",
      "Number of Shows: ",
      map_html_geo$number_shows
    ) |>
      lapply(htmltools::HTML)
  ) |> 
  addLegend("bottomright", pal = pal, values = map_html_geo$occurred,
    title = "Event Status",
    opacity = 1
  )

Tip




annual_hi_gross_tours <-
  ind_html[[9]] |>
  clean_names()


annual_hi_gross_tours_clean <-
  annual_hi_gross_tours |>
  dplyr::mutate(across(
    c(adjusted_gross_in_2022_dollar,
      actual_gross),
    ~ as.numeric(str_replace_all(.x, "[$,]", ""))
  ),
  year = lubridate::ymd(year, truncated = 2L),
  decade = as.factor(floor_date(year, years(10)))) |> 
  add_row(artist = "Taylor Swift",
          tour_title = "The Eras Tour (Expected)",
          year = lubridate::date("2023-01-01"),
          shows = 146,
          adjusted_gross_in_2022_dollar = 1400000000,
          decade = "2020-01-01",
          .before = 1)


annual_hi_gross_tours_clean |>
  ggplot(aes(
    x = year,
    y = adjusted_gross_in_2022_dollar,
    fill = decade
  )) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") +
  geom_smooth(aes(group = decade)) +
  scale_size(range = c(0, 4)) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    text = element_text(size = 9,
                        family = "lato"),
    title = element_text(size = 16,
                         family = "abril-fatface"),
    panel.background = element_blank(),
    axis.ticks.x = element_blank(),
    axis.text.x = element_blank(),
    axis.title.x = element_blank(),
    axis.title.y = element_blank()) +
  geom_text(aes(label = tour_title),
            family = "lato",
            vjust = -2.5,
            angle = 45,
            size = 2) +
  labs(title = "Annual highest-grossing tours")

annual_hi_gross_tours_clean |>
  ggplot(aes(
    x = shows,
    y = adjusted_gross_in_2022_dollar,
    fill = decade
  )) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5,
             shape = 21,
             color = "black") +
  scale_size(range = c(0, 4)) +
  scale_fill_viridis(discrete = TRUE,
                     guide = FALSE,
                     option = "A") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    legend.position = "none",
    text = element_text(size = 9,
                        family = "lato"),

                         family = "abril-fatface"),
    panel.background = element_blank(),
    axis.ticks.x = element_blank(),
    axis.title.x = element_blank(),
    axis.title.y = element_blank()
  ) +
  labs(title = "Number of shows vs. income")

url2 <-
  "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_most-attended_concert_tours"

url_bow2 <- polite::bow(url2)
url_bow2

<polite session> https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_most-attended_concert_tours
    User-agent: polite R package
    robots.txt: 456 rules are defined for 33 bots
   Crawl delay: 5 sec
  The path is scrapable for this user-agent

ind_html2 <-
  polite::scrape(url_bow2) |>  # scrape web page
  rvest::html_nodes("table.wikitable") |> # pull out specific table
  rvest::html_table(fill = TRUE)

ind_tab2 <-
  ind_html2[[2]] |>
  janitor::clean_names() |>
  dplyr::mutate(tickets_sold = as.numeric(str_replace(tickets_sold, " million.*", "")) * 1e6)

tours_by_decade2 <-
  tours_by_decade |>
  dplyr::mutate(
    tour_title = case_when(
      tour_title == "Music of the Spheres World Tour ‚Ä†" ~ "Music of the Spheres World Tour",
      tour_title == "The Garth Brooks World Tour" ~ "The Garth Brooks World Tour (1996‚Äì1998)",
      tour_title == "Steel Wheels Tour" ~ "Steel Wheels/Urban Jungle Tour",
      .default = tour_title
    )
  )

cost_per <-
  left_join(ind_tab2, tours_by_decade2, join_by(tour_title))


cost_per |>
  mutate(cost_per = adjusted_gross_in_2022_dollar / tickets_sold) |>
  ggplot(aes(x = year, y = cost_per)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm")

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'


Warning: Removed 1 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_smooth()`).


Warning: Removed 1 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`).
